title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #632: The (a,b)-Choosability Scaling Conjecture**

If G is (a,b)-choosable, is G also (am,bm)-choosable for all m ≥ 1?

**Answer**: NO (DISPROVED by Dvořák-Hu-Sereni 2019)

Fails at (4,1) → (8,2): there exists a graph that is (4,1)-choosable but NOT (8,2)-choosable.

title: Graph
content:
**Graph V** = SimpleGraph V

A simple undirected graph on vertex set V.

title: Color Assignment
content:
**ColorAssignment V a** = V → Finset (Fin a)

Assigns to each vertex a list of available colors from {0, 1, ..., a-1}.

title: Valid Assignment
content:
**IsValidAssignment(L)**: Each vertex gets exactly a colors.

∀ v, |L(v)| = a

title: Color Selection
content:
**ColorSelection V a** = V → Finset (Fin a)

A function picking a subset of colors for each vertex.

title: Valid Selection
content:
**IsValidSelection(L, S, b)**: Each selection has exactly b colors from the list.

∀ v, S(v) ⊆ L(v) ∧ |S(v)| = b

title: Selections Disjoint
content:
**SelectionsDisjoint(G, S)**: Adjacent vertices have disjoint color selections.

∀ u v, G.Adj u v → S(u) ∩ S(v) = ∅

title: (a,b)-Choosability
content:
**IsChoosable(G, a, b)**: For ANY assignment of a colors to each vertex, there EXISTS a selection of b colors from each list such that adjacent vertices have disjoint selections.

This is the central definition of the problem.

title: List Chromatic ≤ a
content:
**listChromaticNumber_le(G, a)** = IsChoosable G a 1

(a,1)-choosability is exactly χ_L(G) ≤ a.

title: List Chromatic Number
content:
**listChromaticNumber(G)** = min { a | IsChoosable G a 1 }

The minimum number of colors needed for list coloring.

title: χ_L ≥ χ
content:
**list_chromatic_ge_chromatic**: χ_L(G) ≥ χ(G)

List chromatic number is at least the ordinary chromatic number.

title: Monotonicity in a
content:
**choosable_mono_a**: More colors available makes it easier.

a₁ ≤ a₂ → IsChoosable G a₁ b → IsChoosable G a₂ b

title: Anti-monotonicity in b
content:
**choosable_mono_b**: Fewer colors to select makes it easier.

b₁ ≥ b₂ → IsChoosable G a b₁ → IsChoosable G a b₂

title: ERT Conjecture
content:
**ERT_Conjecture** (DISPROVED):

∀ G a b m, m ≥ 1 → IsChoosable G a b → IsChoosable G (a*m) (b*m)

This is the scaling property that Erdős, Rubin, and Taylor conjectured.

title: Trivial Case m = 1
content:
**ert_m_eq_1**: The conjecture holds trivially for m = 1.

IsChoosable G a b → IsChoosable G (a*1) (b*1)

title: Case m = 2
content:
**ERT_Case_m2**: The m = 2 case.

∀ G a b, IsChoosable G a b → IsChoosable G (2a) (2b)

This is the first non-trivial case.

title: (4,1) → (8,2) Case
content:
**ERT_Case_4_1_to_8_2**: Does (4,1)-choosable imply (8,2)-choosable?

This is the specific case that DHS disproved.

title: (4,1) → (8,2) FALSE
content:
**ert_4_1_to_8_2_false**: ¬ERT_Case_4_1_to_8_2

The (4,1) → (8,2) case is FALSE.

title: DHS Counterexample
content:
**dhs_counterexample**: The Dvořák-Hu-Sereni theorem.

∃ G, IsChoosable G 4 1 ∧ ¬IsChoosable G 8 2

This disproves the ERT conjecture.

title: DHS Graph Structure
content:
**dhs_graph_structure**: The counterexample graph has n > 100 vertices.

The construction is detailed in [DHS19].

title: Bad Assignment
content:
**dhs_bad_assignment**: There exists a color assignment with 8 colors such that no valid 2-selection makes adjacent vertices disjoint.

This is the key to the counterexample.

title: m = 2 Case FALSE
content:
**ert_m2_false**: ¬ERT_Case_m2

The m = 2 case of the conjecture is false.

Proof: Follows from ert_4_1_to_8_2_false.

title: Conjecture FALSE
content:
**ert_conjecture_false**: ¬ERT_Conjecture

The Erdős-Rubin-Taylor conjecture is FALSE.

Proof: The m = 2 case fails, so the general conjecture fails.

title: Erdős #632 DISPROVED
content:
**erdos_632**: ¬ERT_Conjecture

Erdős Problem #632 is DISPROVED.

title: Fractional Scales
content:
**fractional_choosability_scales**: Fractional choosability DOES scale.

Contrast: Integer (a,b)-choosability does NOT scale.

title: Complete Graphs
content:
**complete_graph_ert**: For complete graphs, the ERT conjecture holds.

Special graph classes can satisfy the scaling property.

title: Bipartite Graphs
content:
**bipartite_ert**: For bipartite graphs, the ERT conjecture holds.

Another class where scaling works.

title: Ohba's Theorem
content:
**ohba_noel_reed_wu**: χ_L(G) = χ(G) when |V| ≤ 2χ(G) + 1.

A related result about when list chromatic equals chromatic.

title: Final Result
content:
**erdos_632_disproved**: ¬ERT_Conjecture

**Summary**: The (a,b)-choosability scaling conjecture is FALSE.

Dvořák-Hu-Sereni (2019) showed (4,1)-choosable does NOT imply (8,2)-choosable.
